p: About 67% of respondents believed that climate change is controllable, as compared with 13% who believed it is uncontrollable. The majority of respondents (>80%) agreed that climate change has negative impacts on the public in general and for human health specifically. Over 85% of respondents anticipated serious health impacts of climate change in the next 20 years at the local, national, and international levels. These perceptions were consistent across different streams of students, except that the public health students were more likely ( p < 0.01) to believe climate change is controllable ( Table 2).
